docs.title: Haynes Cigar Journal
docs.text: This is so I don't lose track of the notes I take while smoking cigars.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
• NC Reviews: Reviews of cigars from Nicaragua, Dominican Republic, Honduras, and other countries
  • CC Reviews: Reviews of authentic Cuban cigars from Habanos S.A.

docs.title: About the Author
docs.text: Coming Soon

docs.title: Wrapper Types
docs.text:
Connecticut Shade - Light, creamy, mild flavor - Notes: Hay, cedar, cream, light spice

Connecticut Broadleaf - Rich, earthy, full-bodied - Notes: Chocolate, coffee, earth, leather

Habanos (Cuban) - Medium to full, complex - Notes: Cedar, honey, citrus, earth, floral

Maduro - Dark, sweet, rich - Notes: Dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, earth

Corojo - Spicy, full-bodied - Notes: Black pepper, spice, wood, leather

Criollo - Medium-bodied, balanced - Notes: Cedar, nuts, light spice, cream

Candela - Light, grassy, mild - Notes: Grass, hay, light sweetness

docs.title: Binder & Filler Origins
docs.text:
Nicaragua - Full-bodied, spicy, bold - Notes: Black pepper, earth, wood, cocoa

Dominican Republic - Medium-bodied, smooth, balanced - Notes: Cedar, nuts, cream, light spice

Honduras - Medium to full, rich - Notes: Earth, wood, spice, cocoa

Cuba - Medium to full, complex - Notes: Cedar, honey, citrus, earth, floral, spice

Ecuador - Medium-bodied wrapper source - Notes: Cedar, cream, nuts, light spice

Mexico - Earthy, rich - Notes: Earth, coffee, dark chocolate, spice

Brazil - Full-bodied, rich - Notes: Earth, coffee, dark chocolate, spice

docs.title: CC Reviews
docs.text: Welcome to the Cuban cigar reviews section. Here you'll find detailed reviews of authentic Cuban cigars from Habanos S.A. and other Cuban manufacturers.

docs.title: Recent Reviews
docs.text: Coming soon - reviews will be added here

docs.title: Cuban Brands
docs.text:
• Cohiba: The flagship brand of Cuban cigars
  • Montecristo: Classic Cuban flavor profiles
  • Partagás: Bold and spicy characteristics
  • Romeo y Julieta: Traditional Cuban craftsmanship
  • H. Upmann: Smooth and refined profiles
  • Bolívar: Full-bodied Cuban strength
  • Hoyo de Monterrey: Medium-bodied elegance
  • Punch: Traditional Cuban heritage
  • Ramon Allones: Rich and complex Cuban profiles

docs.title: Cuban Vitolas
docs.text: Cuban cigars come in traditional vitolas (sizes): - Robusto: 4.9" x 50 ring gauge - Torpedo: 6.1" x 52 ring gauge - Churchill: 7" x 47 ring gauge - Corona: 5.6" x 42 ring gauge - Petit Corona: 4.5" x 42 ring gauge - Lancero: 7.5" x 38 ring gauge

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Coronas Major Tubo 0 - -

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 2025-11-09
docs.text: Toothy looking cigar. Smoke starts creamy with silky texture and notes of almonds. Distinct Cuban taste that’s starting to evolve into notes of graham crust. There’s a bit of sweetness to it as well, like a honey biscuit. As the cigar burns down past the midpoint the creamy texture starts to switch to leather. Small oil pockets show up on the ash which match the toothyness of this one. Smoked great down to the nub. Mellowed out with a nice oak finish. No burn issues, never once had to course correct it.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Le Hoyo du Depute 1 2025-10-29 9.1

docs.title: Review 1 - Tiny - 10/29
docs.text:
Box Code: MAR 2023

Hope not ROTT! This is a little Cuban cutie. Packs a bit of a punch right of the bat with spice and pepper. Smoke is plenty and is quickly feeling creamy. Mouth flavor picks up as the first third burns by. Very tasty buttery bread and you can tell it’s Cuban tobacco. Crazy amount of smoke for such a little stick. Pepper is gone and it’s very creamy bready goodness. A hint of sweet is creeping in. Nearing the end it’s worth calling out that the burn has been perfect. This is convenient since a touch up with my torch could be risky. The flavor intensified a bit but the notes remain the same. The sweetness didn’t pick up but I don’t think I’ve ever had anything this buttery. 10/10 for a 45F night but smaller than I’d usually grab.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Double Edmundo 1 2025-10-26 90 No 2 1 2025-11-14 100

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 10/26
docs.text: Cigar over a year old but still very fresh. Cut, draw, and toast went great. Hit with some pepper out of the gate, construction seems spot on. Further in I catch a bit of bread on my tongue with that unique Cuban taste. The cigar starts to open up in the second third with ample velvet smoke. Cedar and cocoa start to creep in as the pepper subsides. Familiar notes often seem offset with something hard to describe. Like buttered bread but from a zesty loaf that hasn’t been invented yet. As the zest begins to fade the cocoa power shifts to a full on dark chocolate spread over savory buttered bread. Velvet smooth smoke draws easily from the cigar. The final third smooths out with creamy smoke that’s still savory with that buttered bread note.

docs.title: Review 1 - Torpedo - 2025-11-14
docs.text: Flavorful from the start with cedar notes, nome zest, and creamy smoke. Flavor picks up big time as the first third goes down. Some cocoa sweetness but that distinct Cuban deliciousness is hitting good. Notes on the tongue are great, savory and earthy but hard to put a name to. Some plumb or other less sweet fruit too. Some pepper presents itself on the retrohale of the final third. Espresso and cedar on the tongue.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Serie D No 4 1 2025-11-15 95

docs.title: Review 1 - Robusto - 2025-11-15
docs.text: Lights up into tons of smoke and some pepper on the nose. Some chocolate sweetness emerges as it burns down a bit with a toasty note of almond. The smoke is now velvety smooth with more sweet notes on the retrohale than pepper. Cigar is into the second third. That distinct Cuban flavor fills my mouth with every puff, I’m going to need to rotate some NWs in so I don’t come to rely on its wonder. The final third looses its sweetness and gets a bit more bitter, like milk chocolate evolving into baking chocolate. This helps the pepper sneak through the retrohale but wrapped in oak and leather. Very pleasant cigar, wonder if I’ve got any boxes of these to age on the way…

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating No 54 1 2025-11-05 75

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 2025-11-05
docs.text: JUN2024 box. Mild spice to start but not pepper, more baking. Almost peanut buttery smoke with a bit of bread. They made this for the French so that’ll be the theme. As the pepper settles a sweet honey begins to mingle with the baguette. Half way in starting to get a bit of a yeasty zest, poppin like a fresh loaf. Turns out the cigar is actually named after a very important French street. The age of this one is definitely showing. It’s good but I think another 6-12 months will really bring out the greatest. The sweet and bready notes are fleeting as the final third burns down. Oak and leather are pretty strong and there’s still that zing of baking pepper on the retrohale.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Perla 1 2025-11-07 N/A

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? 2025-11-07
docs.text: Nice little stick. Didn't pay much attention to it though.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Specially Selected 1 2025-11-05 8.2 No 3 1 2025-11-10 70

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 2025-11-10
docs.text: First garagegar! Starts with a little spice but with that distinctive Cuban flavor mixed in. Notes of black coffee and baking chocolate. Smoke gets creamy rounding the second third. Notes are nutty and sweet, maybe toasted peanuts. The final third is a bit more leathery with a touch of molasses. Wasn’t bad but less impressive than some of the others.

docs.title: Review 1 - FEB25 - 11/05
docs.text: These are fresh, from FEB25 but I’ve been told they are OK early. Over toasted it cause I can’t see the flame but draw is great and things even out. Starts out fairly mild almost hay but with a nice twang. There is a touch of spice as the smoke exits my nose but it’s ever fleeting. Some sweet chocolate enters the pallet as we round the half way point. Into the second half and the moisture in the smoke gives it a nice creamy texture when exhaled. When held and retrohailed notes of leather and wood pop. It’s worth calling out that the burn has been great and the draw perfect, I’ve been lucky with the construction of the Cubans I’ve tried so far. Chocolate took on a bit of an espresso finish, the final third stayed cool.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Wide Churchill 1 2025-10-18 99 No 2 Tubo 0 2025-11-12 85

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 2025-11-12
docs.text: Draw was a little tight but it was an easy fix. Very pleasant from the start. Not much pepper but notes of cedar and flowers. Smoke starts to get creamy into the second third, notes of almond. Enjoying this stick a lot with a late breakfast. Floral notes are gone in the final third but what is left is very tasty. Savory notes like roasted nut and cocoa

docs.title: Review 1 - Robusto? - 10/18
docs.text: What a great stick to start my Cuban journey with. Initial notes of Cedar but quickly got a fluffy Almond as I got into it with a bit of fruity zest. The zest evolved into a cherry honey note that followed the cigar down to the nub. No construction or burn issues at all. My cut was great but I over toasted some of the leaf, seems a bit easier to do with Cubans, but I was able to fix that right after I got into it.

docs.title: NC Reviews
docs.text: Welcome to the Non-Cuban cigar reviews section. Here you'll find detailed reviews of cigars from Nicaragua, Dominican Republic, Honduras, and other countries outside of Cuba.

docs.title: Recent Reviews
docs.text: Coming soon - reviews will be added here

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating OpusX Lost City 1 2025-11-01 8.3

docs.title: Review 1 - Toro(?) - 11/1
docs.text: This cigar has a backstory which drew me in. It starts off leathery and dry with notes of cedar. There is some pepper but subtle instead of the main attraction. Smoke starts turning a bit creamier after the first third. Almond notes come out with a hit of sweetness. Midway through things blend a bit together. Retrohale is less pepper more smooth, maybe oaky. Smoke is thick on my tongue like a molasses coating. As the final third approaches the sweetness is just an echo, melding into notes of dark coffee.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating The King Is Dead 1 2025-10-22 8/*10

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 10/22
docs.text: Lit up well with notes of toast and honey. Densely packed and needed a poke from the draw tool. Bit of pepper in the retrohale. Sweetness picks up at the second third and it’s like syrup and caramel. Some of the notes are unique to this session. Bit more savory at the end, but earthy but still a touch of caramel. Aged oak barrels like The Late Hour come to mind. Pleasant finish to a surprising complex cigar.

docs.title: Davidoff
docs.text:
Davidoff is unmatched in quality and consistancy. I found most of there Cigars to be enjoyable but some were quite strong.

If you are just starting to explore their offerings I'd recommend smaller ring gauges. I found that I enjoyed their cigars that had a higher ration of wrapper to filler. The Grand Toro's I tried need to be smoked slowely if you want to make it to the end.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Winston Churchill The Late Hour 1 2025-09-20 8/10 Signature 1 2025-09-21 8/10 Millennium 1 2025-09-27 9/10 Yamasa 1 2025-09-28 9/10 Grand Cru 2 2025-10-05 10/10 Nicaragua 1 2025-10-06 9/10 Escurio 1 2025-10-14 8/10 Winston Churchill 1 2025-10-25 9/10

docs.title: More Information
docs.text: Check out this YouTube documentary to get an inside look at Davidoff as a company.

docs.title: Review 1 - Toro - 10/14
docs.text: Peppery zest at the start. Toasted for an easy light with a V cut. Draw perfect as always. A light sweetness blows gently away with the pepper. Davidoff says it’s the “Brazilian Spark”. Bit of a citrus note. Creamier texture in the second third. Powerful cigar, need to slow down. Coffee notes that have a leathery flow. Maybe best described as a nougat pudding. Finish turns earthy and a little less flavorful.

docs.title: Review 1 - Toro - 10/5
docs.text: Went with a V cut and was met with a ton of smoke off the bat. Having it with my morning coffee which is pairing fine now. Woody at the start with a little cracker, mild so far. Some burn issues but I botched the toast cause it’s super bright out and the flame was invisible. Further into the first third there’s a dash of sweetness, like a honey almond glaze on a fresh pastry. Complexity is there but not a mind fuck like The Late Hour. Moving into the second third I pick up the now familiar “Davidoff Earth” note. No wet leaves today though, more like sunrise in a wheat field. Dew still fresh and the air hazy warm. The dew starts to evaporate in the final third bringing in white pepper on the retrohale. Some light coffee notes mix into the earth which brings a change of scenery. That notable Davidoff flavor is still there but is no longer puzzling, it’s now expected. As I smoke more of their offerings I start to appreciate it more and appreciate each one more than the previous. It’s going to be difficult to rank these without smoking each one twice. I thought the Yamasa stole the show but the Grand Cru is impressing me in different ways. I’m sure I missed a lot in my earlier reviews.

docs.title: Millennium
docs.text:
Review 1 - Toro - 9/27

After a little break from Davidoff I’m back at it. Starts off very pleasant with an oak body and sweet raisin retrohale. For the second chapter I’m picking up something nutty but the smoke is also becoming more creamy. This combination is leading to a pleasant taste with a wonderful mouth feel. I’m enjoying this more than my first two Davidoff but I think the smaller vitola is helping the most. Cream starts bringing in a bit of leather on my tongue, starting to pick up an earthiness I caught on the other Davidoffs. Some pepper comes in at the end, not creamy anymore. Bit of espresso has taken the place of the sweet raisin.

docs.title: Review 1 - Toro - 10/6
docs.text: Spice bomb at the start but with nice caramel notes on my tongue. The flavor quickly evolves and is quite sweet. Starting to be creamy as well but still bold. Notes of brown sugar in the retrohale and complex earth on the tongue. Some people may say notes from the volcanic ash on the soil but how the hell would you know what that tasted like. As the cigar burns further the complexity continues to impress. Noted of tobacco come in with a little spice. The cigar is stronger than I expected and I need to remind myself to slow down. The finish is clean, slightly spicy, but mostly wood & earth.

docs.title: Review 1 - Grand Toro - 9/21
docs.text: After The Late Hour I wanted to hit the other side of the Davidoff spectrum. Smoke starts off clean and creamy with some toasted bread hitting the tongue. Retrohail is still evolving but I catch some white pepper tingling my noise thats wrapped in cedar. As we enter the second half the complexity ramps up, something savory creeps in. Nutty notes afloat with a bit of earth and hay. It also shares a hidden note I couldn’t place last night that may be truffle. The retrohale continues to be a tease with just a dash of pepper. No overpowering sweet note like a lot of the maduros share. The end of the cigar shifts the a more nutty, less bready note. Very smooth retrohale, more floral than pepper at this point.

docs.title: Review 1 - Grand Toro - 9/20
docs.text: Here we go into the Davidoff saga! Good cut on this one, burn is almost even. The cigar is beautifully crafted and feels great in my hands. Quickly I’ve realized that this is a complex cigar. Initial notes are hard to place. Creamy, sweet but malty rather than chocolate or fruits, bit of pepper in the retrohail. I catch the oak when I hold the smoke in my mouth. Sophisticated would be my one word description… I’m a bit over my head with this one. In the 2/3 I’m catching an earthy note with the oak, mainly when I slowly push the smoke out my mouth. Like the oat is now retuning to the earth. A fallen tree. It is as if I’m playing a subtle game with the cigar as it guides me through a late autumn forest. The sun is periodically beaming through the wood offering a malt sweetness. The fallen leaves are damp, oak that will soon be earth. The wind is picking up, crisp and cold pepper that becomes ever more present. The pepper picks up in the final third and the oak is now charred. The creamy smoke at the start is now more powdery like cocoa with charred wood dust.

docs.title: Winston Churchill
docs.text:
Review 1 - Toro - 10/25

The last of my batch of 4 packs! I will revisit each in the spring but this is likely my last Davidoff until then as it’s getting too cold for a toro. Smoke is rich and creamy from the start. Almost buttery. Cedar notes with pepper on the retrohail. Very quickly into it a hint of sweetness wrapped caramel rolls off my tongue but it’s wrapped in that savory earth I catch in Davidoff. The sweet note is more like honey than caramel now and works great withy the fresh earth body. It’s outdoorsy but elegant. The earth and honey has died down now as I burn down towards the final third, getting toasted oak or something of that nature. Maybe some coffee which I am also drinking. The final third tapers down to enjoyable notes of wood and leather with some light spice. The nicotine is strong like other Davidoff’s reminding me to go slow with the larger vitolas.

docs.text: Coming Soon

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Undercrown 10 2 2025-09-04 7/10 Liga Privada Anniversario 1 2025-09-07 8/10 Liga Privada T52 1 2025-09-07 9/10 Liga Privada No. 9 2 2025-09-08 10/10

docs.title: Review 2 - ?? - 9/7
docs.text: Solid smoke. Lots of sweet chocolate starting early into the cigar. Feels premium. Very full bodied, wouldn’t be a daily driver given how powerful the flavor is.

docs.title: Review 1 - Toro - 9/8
docs.text: Silky smooth like the others. Little pepper at the start but quickly fills with a touch of chocolate. More balanced than the other two Liga Privada’s but still very full, not for the golf course.

docs.title: Review 2 - Toro - 11/9
docs.text: Went way too long without one of these, was the Davidoffs then Cubans. Little pepper at the start (again) with creamy smoke. Quickly makes its way to a mouthful of dark chocolate, but unsweetened like baking chocolate. Smoking it too fast has been a mistake but it’s cold now, though 50F tonight is a treat from 40F. The chocolate has moved to a dryer espresso and some dry fruit notes emerge. Getting close to the final third.

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/7
docs.text: Two in one day! Though it’s starting off nothing like the Anniversario 10 except for how buttery smooth it is. Swill sweet but more pepper. Anniversario 10 felt more like a treat while this is in between a treat and a meal. No 9 is even less rich so it will be interesting to see how it compares, hopefully soon!

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/4
docs.text: An alternative to the maduro (which I already have a box of). Spice further in than the other two undercrown. Smooth and sweeter towards the label. Great burn, think I’m hitting the sweet spot of humidity.

docs.title: Review 2 - ?? - 9/4
docs.text: Breakfast cigar today. No humidity issues anymore thanks to the 62% jar. Burn starting off great. Tons of smoke. Notes of sweet chocolate, mild spice. Goes well with my chocolate donut and coffee.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Series B 11/16 1 2025-11-16 82

docs.title: Review 1 - Double Robusto - 11/16/2025
docs.text: Well constructed and easy to like expensive stick. Starts off like a spicy hot chocolate which I guess is sometimes known as a Mexican cocoa. Right from the bat I can see this is going to be a complex one and was a great choice for a NC after my CC binge. Some cedar notes mixed into the silky smooth smoke. Raisin and brown sugar come in as the first third transitions into the second. Smoke is heavier now too. Getting to the end of the second third yields some hefty chocolate notes with some lingering sweetness of dry fruit. The smoke is plentiful but drier now, less creamy. The flavors in this stick are great but for some reason I can’t get it to burn evenly. Too many touch ups knock a few points up but a problem just for this stick and not the line. Been storing this with 62% bovedas, usually get a great burn that way.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating La Nox 1 2025-10-31 9.3

docs.title: Rview 1 - Toro - 10/31
docs.text: Subconscious made this my Halloween pick, great choice! It’s starts right off with cocoa notes and creamy smoke. Not much pepper on this stick but it’s there. Might even say some licorice here. The cigar gets smoother as it’s smoked down melding into more chocolate notes with great white ash. Pleasant flavor but I don’t find them perplexing. One of my go to sticks because of how easy I find them to smoke. Dark and oily like a LP No9 but demands less of my attention. Easy to get lost in thought while smoking and forget to update the review…. 100% box worthy. Gets a bit more sweet towards the end. Licorice transforms into dried fruit.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Le Bijou 1922 1 2025-10-28 8/10

docs.title: Review 1 - Churchill - 10/28
docs.text: I always remember these as pepper bombs but I missed the dried fruit sweetness on the tongue. Pepper certainly does over power the retrohale from the start. The pepper dies down as you’d expect it would but doesn’t exit. The sweetness mellows to a cocoa and coffee notes creep in. More spice, spice bomb for longer than others. Flavors continue to mellow into a pleasant chocolate near the end but the spice still doesn’t quit. The smoke is also getting creamy towards the end, very full.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating Series V Melanio Maduro 1 2025-09-19 8/10

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/19
docs.text: This cigar and its Series V siblings are very popular on Reddit. They deserve a side by side session, and all not that, but just got the Melanio Meduro now. I had trouble getting this one going, hit an air pocket plus my cut was off so we needed a couple touch ups. Fortunately I did good and we evened out for photo #1. At this point I’m getting notes of dried fruit and cinnamon. Deeper in I hit some graham cracker which goes quite well with the other flavors. Photo #2 things started to mellow out to notes of toast and fruit with the cinnamon spice melting away.

docs.title: Reviews
docs.text: Cigar Number of Reviews Date of First Review Rating 1964 Natural 1 2025-09-02 9/10 1964 Maduro 1 2025-09-06 10 1926 Natural 1 2025-09-09 10 1926 Maduro 1 2025-09-18 10 3000 Maduro 1 2025-09-05 10

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/18
docs.text: After a long break from a cold it’s time to round out the Padron reviews. I smoked a La Nox the night before this to make sure I was good to go. Out of the gate I’m hit with more pepper than LPs or La Nox. Wonderful start to the burn, nice and even (and I dropped this one so I was worried). Starts to wrap into a nutty spice. Later the nutty pepper starts to Chase a mild sweetness which does not overpower the other notes. Google says this one is for celebrations but I disagree. Certainly not for the yard or golf course but well balanced enough to be in my regular nightly rotation.

docs.title: Review 2 - ?? - 10/3
docs.text: V cut this time which worked well with the torpedo-ish vitola. Gonna use the term spice bomb for the initial puffs but with a hint of something delicious. Can taste it more in my mouth at this point, but nutty and more creamy. Cocoa roars in during the second half. The smell left after each puff is delightful.

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/9
docs.text: After a long stretch of LP this was a nice change up. This was a Belicosco from Pardron which was more of a torpedo than I imagined but a welcome change from the Toros. Spice hit harder than the LPs right off the bat and the smoke was more Smokey and less creamy. Starts to smooth out an inch down with more prominent sweet tobacco. Rounding out the cigar was definitely more mellow than the sweet “desert” LPs I just had. Little sweet, caramel coffee vibe. 9/10

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/6
docs.text: Smooth sailing, little more spice at first that the natural. Burn started off beautifully, starting to pick up a sweet raisin. Past the half way hitting a more mellow blend of sweet nuts. Even finish, next steps to try the 1926 Natural & Maduro.

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/2
docs.text: Started smooth with some woody pepper notes in retrohale. Sweeter second half, still extremely smooth. Not as sweet as some others I’ve smoked recently. Lost box shape towards the end but smooth musky finish. Hints of cocoa but not as much as I expected. Recommendation: smoke Maduro soon and the other Natural come spring.

docs.title: Review 1 - ?? - 9/5
docs.text: Humidity sees great now, the burn was perfect. Smoked with breakfast, wasn’t overpowering but a bit of spice and sweetness. Very good for the price but was missing a lot of the flavor I’m use to. Think I like Undercrown better as my affordable stick.
